Award.AwardTitle: Sixteenth Annual Symposium of the NSF Astronomy and Astrophysics Postdoctoral Fellows
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will provide support for the attendees and invited speakers for the sixteenth Annual Symposium of the NSF Astronomy and Astrophysics Postdoctoral Fellows, to be held in conjunction with the winter meeting of the American Astronomical Society in January 2018, in National Harbor, Maryland. The purpose of the Astronomy and Astrophysics Postdoctoral Fellowships (AAPF) Program is to support integrated research and educational activities at the postdoctoral level to better prepare its fellows for positions of distinction and leadership in the scientific community. The Annual Symposium provides a forum for the Fellows to discuss their research and education projects while increasing their visibility within the astronomy and astrophysics community. The Symposium represents a key component of the AAPF Program and is a very effective mechanism to facilitate the transfer of knowledge from experiences that the Fellows have acquired through their postdoctoral training to a broad audience.

As with previous symposia in this series, the 2018 AAPF Symposium will promote interactions among astronomers with diverse research interests and backgrounds. By creating a forum in which discussions can occur across traditional research boundaries, the Symposium will provide Fellows the opportunity to gain new insights and pursue interdisciplinary collaborations. The Symposium will also provide a venue for discussing major issues that are important to early-career astronomers. In addition, the Symposium will (1) provide a forum for discussing integrated research and educational activities, (2) facilitate collaborations between Fellows on both research and education, and (3) provide greater exposure for the Fellows and the AAPF Program within the astronomical community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant funded the 2018 NSF Astronomy and Astrophysics Postdoctoral Fellowship Symposium which took place at the 231st AAS meeting in Washington, DC. The symposium occurs once a year and provides four excellent opportunities: 1) for the NSF AAPFs to interact and learn about each others' groundbreaking scientific and education efforts; 2) for AAPFs to gain professional development and enrichment; 3) for the broader astronomical community to learn about the AAPF program and fellow’s efforts; 4) for a forum for AAPF fellows to discuss fellowship logistics and common challenges. The symposium ran across two days: Sunday, 7 January, 1:00 to 5:30 pm, and Monday, 8 January, 9:00 am to 5:30 pm at the Gaylord National Resort & Convention Center. The 2018 NSF AAPF symposium was reported as the highest attended by non-fellows and the most discussed on social media during the days prior to the AAS Winter Meeting.

The event was open to all AAS 231 Winter Meeting attendees and featured a number of activities relevant to the broader astronomical community. There were 20 selected talks by fellows on their current research and broader impact efforts; career advice from a panel consisting scientists who earned NSF CAREER awards; and talks by two keynote speakers: Dr. Lucianne Walkowicz, the Blumberg Chair of Astrobiology at the Library of Congress; and Dr. Alex Young, Associate Director for Science in the Heliophysics Science Division of NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center.
